articles.title: Rubio warns Europe of new era in geopolitics before Munich security conference
articles.body: Rubio is expected to avoid taking Vance's abrasive approach but, when asked if he was planning to be more conciliatory, he said that Europeans "want to know where we're going, where we'd like to go, where we'd like to go with them".

articles.title: Watch: How Andrew's BBC interview compares to what Epstein emails tell us now
articles.body:
Following the latest release of the Epstein files, claims made by the then Prince Andrew in a 2019 BBC Newsnight interview can be put under fresh scrutiny.

The BBC’s Sean Coughlan and Sarah Campbell have gone through the interview to compare Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s replies with emails which were apparently sent to and from the former prince.

He is facing growing pressure from US officials and the family of his prominent accuser, the late Virginia Giuffre, to testify in the US about his links to Jeffrey Epstein.

The disgraced financier was convicted in 2008 of procuring a child for prostitution and died by suicide in 2019, as he awaited trial on sex trafficking charges.

The BBC has contacted Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor for comment. He has previously denied any wrongdoing.

articles.title: Trump revokes landmark EPA ruling that greenhouse gases endanger public health
articles.body: "So that includes motor vehicles, but it also includes power plants, the oil and gas sector, methane from landfills, even aircraft. So it really runs the gamut, all of the standards for each of the sectors is premised on this one thing."

articles.title: Bangladesh election: BNP sweeps to victory in first vote since Gen Z uprising
articles.body: "As two close neighbours with deep-rooted historical and cultural ties, I reaffirmed India's continued commitment to the peace, progress, and prosperity of both our peoples," Modi wrote on X.

articles.title: Louvre: Leak damages 19th Century painting in latest setback
articles.body: The ceiling painting, signed by Meynier in 1822, depicts lauded French painters Nicolas Poussin, Eustache Le Sueur, and Charles Le Brun, who appear in the clouds among angelic figures.

articles.title: Iran fortifies underground complex near nuclear site, satellite images show
articles.body: "In the past, Iran has tied the construction to rebuilding an advanced centrifuge assembly plant, but the size of the facility, as well as the protection provided by the tall mountain, raised immediate concern whether additional sensitive activities are planned, such as uranium enrichment," they said.

articles.title: Watch moment Falcon 9 blasts off to International Space Station
articles.body:
The four astronauts that make up SpaceX Crew-12 have begun their journey to the International Space Station (ISS).

Nasa's Jessica Meir and Jack Hathaway, the European Space Agency's Sophie Adenot and Roscosmos's Andrey Fedyaev are all aboard the Falcon 9 rocket as it travels 34 hours to its destination.

The crew will spend eight months on the ISS, replacing a team that evacuated the station last month due to a medical emergency.

"Crew-12 is grateful and ready for the journey ahead", mission commander Jessica Meir said after the launch.

articles.title: Japan says it seized Chinese vessel amid tensions with Beijing
articles.body:
China's Xi Jinping makes rare reference to recent military purge

Zhang Youxia, widely seen as Xi's closest military ally, was in January removed from his post.

1 day ago

articles.title: Angus Taylor ousts Sussan Ley as Australia's Liberal Party leader
articles.body: Reflecting on her time at the helm, Ley said it had been "very tough" at times but added: "I was part of the early punk rock movement in Canberra, I will continue to find wisdom in one of punk's defining themes, a fearless and honest belief in yourself."

articles.title: FBI releases description of suspect in Nancy Guthrie kidnapping
articles.body:
Watch: BBC in Nancy Guthrie's hometown as sniffer dogs help search for clues

Nancy Guthrie, 84, was abducted from her home near Tucson, Arizona, prompting a widespread search and appeals from her family.

1 day ago

articles.title: Cyril Ramaphosa orders SANDF to tackle South Africa gang violence in his Sona
articles.body: Beyond the military deployment, Ramaphosa announced additional measures to combat crime, including recruiting 5,500 police officers, strengthening intelligence, and targeting crime syndicates.

articles.title: Steven Spielberg donates $25,000 to James Van Der Beek's $2m GoFundMe
articles.body: Oscar-winning film director Steven Spielberg and his wife, Kate Capshaw, have donated $25,000 (£21,000) to the $2m (£1.6m) GoFundMe pot collected for the late Dawson's Creek actor James Van Der Beek.

articles.title: Sydney police to be investigated by watchdog after anti-Herzog protest violence
articles.body: Minns has previously defended police actions, saying on Tuesday that police had been "put in an impossible situation", urging the public "not to look at a 10-second clip without the full context".

articles.title: Norway's former PM Jagland charged with gross corruption over Epstein links
articles.body: The Nordic country has seen several public figures drawn into the widening scandal, including Crown Princess Mette-Marit, diplomats Mona Juul and Terje Rød-Larsen, and chief executive of the World Economic Forum (WEF), Borge Brende.

articles.title: 'My husband stole £600k for sex and antiques' - drug side effects tearing families apart
articles.body: "People didn't want to know us, and I can understand that entirely," says Frances, thinking back to what Andrew did. While their daughter, Alice, says her father "never forgave himself".

articles.title: Sussan Ley: Does Liberal Party drama show Australian politics still has a problem with women?
articles.body: "Instead of, as a woman, getting out there and arguing for quotas, standing up for them, Ley came out with this line, which I just thought was BS, about being a zealot for getting more women into parliament, but agnostic on quotas," Savva says.

articles.title: Analysis: Trump takes victory lap after biggest climate rollback yet
articles.body: The rollback sparked fury, meanwhile, among Democrats and environmental groups who said it would wreck the US's ability to combat climate change. "We'll be less safe, less healthy and less able to fight climate change - all so the fossil fuel industry can make even more money," former President Barack Obama wrote on social media.

articles.title: Tumbler Ridge grieves after one of Canada's deadliest mass shootings
articles.body: "We've been insulated," Tracy Krauss, a local pastor, told the BBC. "A newcomer comes to town and they're locking up, and everyone laughs, because why are you doing that? Nothing happens here."

articles.title: Africa-US relations: The continent grapples with the new world order
articles.body: The transactional approach is not necessarily bad, Opalo said, but he argued that there is not the strategic depth of thinking going on, or diplomatic expertise, in African governments "to play this game well". This means leaders may go for easy wins without considering the long-term implications, he feared.

articles.title: Mohammad Deepak: The Hindu who stood up for a Muslim and became a hero in India
articles.body: His follower count on Instagram has swelled and a short video he shared on 29 January has more than five million likes. In it, he says: "I am not a Hindu, I am not a Muslim, I am not a Sikh, I am not a Christian. First and foremost, I am a human being."

articles.body:
Following the latest release of the Epstein files, claims made by the then Prince Andrew in a 2019 BBC Newsnight interview can be put under fresh scrutiny.

The BBC’s Sean Coughlan and Sarah Campbell have gone through the interview to compare Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s replies with emails which were apparently sent to and from the former prince.

He is facing growing pressure from US officials and the family of his prominent accuser, the late Virginia Giuffre, to testify in the US about his links to Jeffrey Epstein.

The disgraced financier was convicted in 2008 of procuring a child for prostitution and died by suicide in 2019, as he awaited trial on sex trafficking charges.

The BBC has contacted Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor for comment. He has previously denied any wrongdoing.

articles.title: 'My son is dead': Swiss bar owners confronted by fire victim families
articles.body:
The owners of a Swiss bar, where a deadly fire broke out on New Year's Eve, killing 41 people and injuring at least 115 others, were heckled by grieving families, as they appeared in court in Switzerland on Thursday.

Jessica and Jacques Moretti are under criminal investigation for involuntary manslaughter, as well as bodily harm and arson through negligence.

articles.title: Watch: Three issues that matter to voters in the Bangladesh election
articles.body:
Bangladesh is heading to the polls in the first election since the 2024 Gen Z uprising that toppled long-serving prime minister Sheikh Hasina.

The BBC's Azadeh Moshiri explains the three key issues that matter to voters.

Follow the story live here.

articles.title: BBC in Tehran sees government's 'political reply' to protests
articles.body:
Authorities in Iran have put on a show of strength to mark the 47th anniversary of the Islamic revolution, weeks after they used unprecedented force to put down anti-government protests.

The BBC is visiting Tehran for the first time since the crackdown, during which at least 6,490 protesters were killed across the country, according to human rights activists.

The BBC's chief international correspondent Lyse Doucet says the bunting lining the capital's streets and large crowds of government supporters embody the image of the nation the government wants to see on the streets: Iranians coming out to show their support for the Islamic Republic and the revolution.

Our correspondent is reporting from Tehran on condition that none of her material is used on the BBC's Persian Service. These restrictions apply to all international media organisations operating in Iran.

articles.title: Emergency call released of boy who swam for hours to save family
articles.body:
Police have released audio of a call between emergency services and a 13-year-old Australian boy who swam for hours to get help for his family after they were swept out to sea earlier in February.

In the call, Austin Appelbee says his siblings - brother Beau, 12, and sister Grace, eight - and their mother were still in the water.

"I don't know what their condition is right now and I'm really scared," he says.

The boy also describes feeling "extremely tired" after the grueling ordeal.

Austin passed out after making the call and was taken to the hospital, where he was told his siblings and mother were found alive and well after being rescued 14km (8.5 miles) offshore.
